2.title: Eliezer Yudkowsky
2.clickbait: Cofounder, with Nick Bostrom, of the field of value alignment theory.

45.title: Corrigibility
45.clickbait: "I can't let you do that, Dave."

72.title: Stub
72.clickbait: This page only gives a very brief overview of the topic. If you're able to, please help expand or improve it!

178.title: Arbital "tag" relationship
178.clickbait: Tags are a way to connect pages that share a common topic.

370.editSummary: reflecting the fact that we only have one type of mark now.
370.title: Arbital mark
370.clickbait: What is a mark on Arbital? When is it created? Why is it important?

597.title: Arbital page clickbait
597.clickbait: The text you are reading right now is clickbait.

17b.title: Arbital lens
17b.clickbait: A lens is a page that presents another page's content from a different angle.

1ln.editSummary: alias. note to self: come back and explain new requisites system.
1ln.title: Arbital requisites
1ln.clickbait: To understand a thing you often need to understand some other things.

1rt.title: Arbital path
1rt.clickbait: Arbital path is a linear sequence of pages tailored specifically to teach a given concept to a user.

2v.title: AI alignment
2v.clickbait: The great civilizational problem of creating artificially intelligent computer systems such that running them is a good idea.

2w.title: Edge instantiation
2w.clickbait: When you ask the AI to make people happy, and it tiles the universe with the smallest objects that can be happy.

3d.title: Arbital
3d.clickbait: Arbital is the place for crowdsourced, intuitive math explanations.

3d9.title: 'Beneficial'
3d9.clickbait: Really actually good.  A metasyntactic variable to mean "favoring whatever the speaker wants ideally to accomplish", although different speakers have different morals and metaethics.

3hs.title: Author's guide to Arbital
3hs.clickbait: How to write intuitive, flexible content on Arbital.

3n.title: Arbital "parent" relationship
3n.clickbait: Parent-child relationship between pages implies a strong, inseparable connection.

41k.title: Total alignment
41k.clickbait: We say that an advanced AI is "totally aligned" when it knows *exactly* which outcomes and plans are beneficial, with no further user input.

5f.title: Preference framework
5f.clickbait: What's the thing an agent uses to compare its preferences?

5s.title: value alignment problem
5s.text:
Disambiguation:  For the research subject that includes the entire edifice of how and why to produce good AIs, see [Value Alignment Theory](ValueAlignment-1).

Gloss:  The problem of creating an [advanced Artificial Intelligence](AdvancedAgents-1) such that running it produces [good outcomes](df_value-1).

Technical summary:  The 'value alignment problem' is how to create an [advanced](AdvancedAgents-1) AI such that running the AI is a good idea / creates beneficial effects / produces outcomes of high '[value](df_value-1)' from one of the possible [standpoints on value](df_value-1).  It would include subproblems like identifying high-value outcomes to the AI and distinguishing them from bad outcomes, or creating an AI that maintains a stable preference framework under self-modification, or creating alarms that identify out-of-bounds system behavior.

# Definition.

The 'value alignment problem' is to describe a design or development methodology for an [advanced](AdvancedAgents-1) AI such that we can justifiably expect running this AI to achieve an [adequate amount] of [value](df_value-1).

# Usefulness.

Singling out the problem on this level of abstraction is a very broad way of stating the challenge that our civilization faces in creating advanced AI, if we need to approach our [value achievement dilemma](ValueAchievementDilemma-1) by trying to create an advanced AI.

The value alignment problem has many subproblems, but many of these subproblems are related.  Most importantly, dealing with '[advanced agents](AdvancedAgents-1)' that are not only intelligent but smarter than you in some or all ways, poses some [interesting new difficulties of safety assurance](AdvancedSafe-1), like the agent trying to actively deceive you about its operating state if you have made a mistake in specifying its goals.  Since these difficulties are common across many subproblems of the value alignment problem, but perhaps not shared by other approaches to value achievement, we can see that the value alignment problem is a useful category in the hierarchy.

Many other pieces of terminology, propositions, policy issues, etctera also seem to be shared across the value alignment problem.  This is the rationale for regarding [Value Alignment Theory](ValueAlignment-1) as a well-packaged research field.

# Place in problem breakdown.

We can see the place of value alignment by considering its parent problem, child problems, grandchildren, and siblings.

- The [value achievement dilemma](ValueAchievementDilemma-1).  How does Earth-originating intelligent life achieve an acceptable proportion of its potential?
  - The **value alignment problem**:  How do we create AIs such that running them produces (global) outcomes of acceptably high value?
      -  The **aligned preference problem**:  How do we create AIs that *want* or *prefer* to cause events that are of high value?  If we accept that we should solve the value alignment problem by creating AIs that prefer or want in particular ways, how do we do that?
             - The **[value identification problem](value_identification-1)**:  How can we pinpoint, in the AI's decision-making, those outcomes that have high 'value'?  (Despite e.g. the [Edge Instantiation](EdgeInstantiation-1) problem.)
             - **[ Do What I Mean]**:  If an AI is following a request to produce some [immediate good], what sort of further checks, information from the AI, model of what the human 'means', etc., can make the genie-wish less unsafe?
       - **[Corrigibility](corrigibility-1)**:  How can we create AIs such that, when we make an error in identifying value or specifying the decision system, the AI does not resist our attempts to correct what we regard as an error?
       - **[Limited AI](RelevantLimited-1)** theory.  AIs which optimize less strongly by virtue of not wanting to optimize more strongly than that (rather than, e.g., AIs which are limited by humans constraining how much computing power the AI is allowed, but where the AI would choose to use more computing power if it had the option).
      - Tripwires and honeypots - how to incorporate features into the AI that are designed to shut it down or trigger other alarms if the AI's behavior has gone outside expected bounds.
  - The intelligence amplification problem.   How can we create smarter humans, preferably without driving them insane or otherwise ending up with evil ones?
  - The value selection problem.  How can we figure out what to substitute in for the metasyntactic variable 'value'?

7g1.title: Sufficiently advanced Artificial Intelligence
7g1.clickbait: 'Sufficiently advanced Artificial Intelligences' are AIs with enough 'advanced agent properties' that we start needing to do 'AI alignment' to them.
